products.label: DevSecOps Solution For Apps
products.name: deploy-arch-ibm-alm-stack
products.short_description: Comprehensive solution with prerequisite services and pipelines from the DevSecOps Foundation for secure app development.
products.long_description:
This deployable architecture provides a comprehensive foundation for trust, observability, security, and regulatory compliance by configuring and deploying various services, including:
- Creates CI/CD/CC Pipelines for secure application lifecycle management.
- Creates and configures a Key Protect instance and creates root keys for IBM Cloud Object Storage, Event Notifications, and Secrets Manager.
- Creates and configures a Secrets Manager instance and creates rotatable secrets required to run secure pipelines.
- Creates and configures an IBM Security Compliance Center instance.
- Creates and configures an IBM Cloud Object Storage instance and multiple Object Storage buckets that are encrypted by Key Protect.
- Deploy and configures service-to-service authorizations for the following services: KMS, Event Notifications, Object Storage, Secrets Manager, and Security and Compliance Center.
- (Optionally) Creates a Code Engine Project for that variation.

# Objective

This deployable architecture is designed to showcase a fully automated deployment of a sample Node application through an IBM Cloud Project, providing a flexible and customizable foundation for your own application deployments on IBM Cloud. This architecture deploys the following [Sample application](https://us-south.git.cloud.ibm.com/open-toolchain/code-engine-compliance-app) by default.

By leveraging this architecture, you can accelerate your deployment and tailor it to meet your unique business needs and enterprise goals.

Please note this product is not supported via the IBM Cloud Support Center.

The pricing plan to use for Secrets Manager.
The pricing plan to use for the IBM Cloud Security and Compliance Center.
The region in which the Security and Compliance Center instance is provisioned.
The region in which the Events Notification instance is created.
Setting to `true` will treat the `resource_group_name` as an existing resource group. Setting `false` will provision a new resource group based on the value in `resource_group_name`.

This is the repository branch used by the default sample application. Alternatively if `app_repo_existing_url` is provided, then the branch must reflect the default branch for that repository. Typically these branches are `main` or `master`.

Bring your own existing application repository by providing the URL. This will create an integration for your application repository instead of cloning the default sample. Repositories existing in a different org will require the use of Git token. See `app_repo_git_token_secret_name` under optional variables.
Name of the Git token secret in the secret provider used for accessing the sample (or bring your own) application repository.
The names of the projects to add the IBM Cloud Code Engine.
The CRN of an existing Secrets Manager instance
Set to `true` to automatically run the CI pipeline.
Set to `true` to use the CI sample application repository as the deployment repository in the CD pipeline. This will be set in the pipeline config integration.

Set to `true` to force create a standard api key. By default the generated apikey will be a service api key. It is recommended to use a Git Token when using the service api key. In the case where the user has been invited to an account and that user not the account owner, during toolchain creation the default compliance repositories will be created in that user's account and the service api will not have access to those repositories. In this case a Git Token for the repositories is required. See `repo_git_token_secret_name` for more details. The alternative is to set `force_create_standard_api_key` to `true` to create a standard api key.
Set to `true` to create a Git Token secret in the speficied Secrets Manager, using the name set in `repo_git_token_secret_name` and the value set in `repo_git_token_secret_value`.

(Optional) The title of the server. e.g. My Git Enterprise Server. Applies to the sample application repository, pipeline config repository and additionally the deployment repository of the CD toolchain. Takes precedence over `repo_title`, if also set.

(Optional) The Root URL of the server. e.g. https://git.example.com. Applies to the sample application repository, pipeline config repository and additionally the deployment repository of the CD toolchain. Takes precedence over `repo_root_url`, if also set.

Setting this value to `true` means the server is not addressable on the public internet. IBM Cloud will not be able to validate the connection details you provide. Certain functionality that requires API access to the git server will be disabled. Delivery pipeline will only work using a private worker that has network access to the git server.

The Git ID for the application repositories. Used by the sample application repository, pipeline config repository and additionally the deployment repository of the CD toolchain. Takes precedence for these repositories over the value set in `repo_git_id`.

Specify the Git user or group for your application. This must be set if the repository authentication type is `pat` (personal access token). Used by the sample application repository, pipeline config repository and additionally the deployment repository of the CD toolchain. Takes precedence for these repositories over the value set in `repo_group`.

The Git provider type. Used by the sample application repository, pipeline config repository and additionally the deployment repository of the CD toolchain. Takes precedence for these repositories over the value set in `repo_git_provider`.

The name of the Git token secret in the secret provider used for accessing the sample application repository, pipeline config repository and additionally the deployment repository of the CD toolchain. Takes precedence for these repositories over the value set in `repo_git_token_secret_name`.

The personal access token that will be added to the `custom_app_repo_git_token_secret_name` secret in the secrets provider. Note if also using `repo_git_token_secret_name` to set a Git Token in Secrets Manager, the names of the secrets must be different.
The name for the Git Token secret in Secrets Manager.
The value of the Git Token secret that is created if `create_git_token` is set to `true`.
The name of the Git repository owner/group. This setting applies to all all the compliance repositories and sample app.

By default this gets set as 'hostedgit', else set to 'githubconsolidated' for GitHub repositories or `gitlab` for GitLab. Applies to all the default DevSecOps repositories, except the `Compliance Pipelines` repository that get created at the time of running the DA.
(Optional) The title of the server. e.g. My Git Enterprise Server.
(Optional) The Root URL of the server. e.g. https://git.example.com.

Setting this value to `true` means the server is not addressable on the public internet. IBM Cloud will not be able to validate the connection details you provide. Certain functionality that requires API access to the git server will be disabled. Delivery pipeline will only work using a private worker that has network access to the git server.
Set this value to `github` for github.com, `gitlabcustom` for GitLab or to the ID of a custom GitHub Enterprise server.
Set to use an existing evidence repository.
Set to use an existing issues repository.
Set to use an existing inventory repository.
Override to bring your own existing deployment repository URL, which is used directly instead of cloning the default deployment sample.
Override to bring your own existing change management repository URL, which is used directly instead of cloning the default change management repository.
Set to `true` to create the triggers used by the DevSecOps pipelines.
Set to `true` to create the Git triggers used by the DevSecOps pipelines.
Set to `true` to apply group level repository settings to the compliance pipeline repository. See `repo_git_provider` as an example.
By default this gets set as 'hostedgit', else set to 'githubconsolidated' for GitHub repositories or `gitlab` for GitLab.
Set this value to `github` for github.com, `gitlabcustom` for GitLab or to the ID of a custom GitHub Enterprise server.
Override to bring your own existing compliance pipelines repository URL, which is used directly instead of cloning the default change compliance pipelines repository.
Set to `true` to add the compliance pipelines definitions to the DevSecOps pipelines.
Set to `true` to add a specified private worker service api key to the Secrets Provider.

Set to `true` to enable private workers for the CI, CD, CC and PR pipelines. A valid service api key must be set in Secrets Manager. The name of this secret can be specified using `privateworker_credentials_secret_name`.
Name of the private worker secret in the secret provider.
The private worker service api key that will be added to the `privateworker_credentials_secret_name` secret in the secrets provider.
